pr_title: SyncClient: Bug fix - Multiple Receive on same client

timeline.message: SyncClient: Bug fix - Multiple Receive on same client

timeline.bodyText: This isn't thread safe, in the time that you check for null, someone else could have set it. Or if it is null, and then you create it, it could possibly overwrite an existing EmitterProcessor that was set in this time.
timeline.author: conniey

replies.bodyText: This should insure against it messageProcessor.compareAndSet(null, newProcessor)
replies.author: hemanttanwar

timeline.bodyText: Will it throw if you call dispose twice?
timeline.author: conniey
conniey

replies.bodyText: doOnNext, doOnError, doOnComplete are for side effects like logging or monitoring. It shouldn't be used as part of the main chain of operations.
replies.author: conniey

timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Between isDisposed() check and dispose() the processor might have changed state. This is not an atomic operation, if that's what you were trying to achieve using the AtomicReference.
timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Same here, this is not an atomic operation.
timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Missing javadoc. Do we need this class in public API surface? This should be in implementation package.
timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need this class? This seems to be just printing some debug info to the console.
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: I should not have checked in, I was trying something else. So  removing it.
replies.author: hemanttanwar

timeline.bodyText: timeout() is not the right operator here. The maxWaitTime param specifies the maximum time to wait before receiving all messages upto maximumMessageCount. timeout() operator will reset the timer after each message is received. Also, if there is a timeout, it will throw an exception which is not what should happen. Instead, it should return all messages until the timeout occurred.
timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.bodyText: What if the existing subscription is still waiting for work? You're going to cancel it?
timeline.author: conniey

timeline.message: moving creation of Emitter processor out of constructor

timeline.bodyText: synchronized : This is because if multiple client are calling receive, we need to ensure that short lived sync subscriber is thread safe.
timeline.author: hemanttanwar

replies.bodyText: You don't need an atomic variable then.
replies.author: conniey

replies.bodyText: You can also synchronize on a lock object rather than on an entire class to scope down how large this critical path is.
replies.author: conniey

replies.bodyText: yes: atomic is not needed  but our Checks during build time complains about it or I had to supress the warning .
replies.author: hemanttanwar

timeline.author: conniey

replies.bodyText: discussed on teams and decided to not change it.
replies.author: hemanttanwar

timeline.bodyText: This overload fetches 256. I was hoping you'd use the overload that specifies the buffer size, so you don't accidentally consume more messages than the user wants to process. EmitterProcessor.create(prefetch, false);
timeline.author: conniey

timeline.bodyText: The general trick is to store the value from your AtomicReference operation in a local variable so you don't keep accessing it. You had already fetched its value in line 631.
timeline.author: conniey
